{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3283833,"name":null,"username":"Yuri","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/yuri/{size}/218839_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-14T02:00:01.765Z","cooked":"

is it viable to use a belt to make a 60:1 max planetary turns to a 180:1 to move the principal arm of the robot (the arm is similar to the unqualified quookas here)

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-01-14T02:00:01.765Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":115,"reads":415,"readers_count":414,"score":658.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":450055,"topic_slug":"180-1-max-planetary-60-1-belt-3-1","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FURTxVVXUfM","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":21}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62012,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"I like making sparks with batteries"},"post_url":"/t/180-1-max-planetary-60-1-belt-3-1/450055/1","custom_user_title":"I like making sparks with batteries","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3283838,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-14T02:10:37.422Z","cooked":"

You might run into belt issues with that much torque. Depends on the application, of course. If belt isn’t strong enough, try chain.

Also remember more teeth of engagement, more better

It might work for 2x 100t pulleys but not 2x 18t

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-01-14T02:10:37.422Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":396,"readers_count":395,"score":119.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":450055,"topic_slug":"180-1-max-planetary-60-1-belt-3-1","display_username":"Chadfrom7226","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20021,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/180-1-max-planetary-60-1-belt-3-1/450055/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3283840,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-14T02:11:50.015Z","cooked":"

Sure in theory, but it’s going to depend on the weight and COM of the arm, the size of the pulleys, how fast you want to move the arm etc. There are 3 ways to figure this out. Have experienced people around who are good at guessing. Calculate everything, figure out the mass, COM, and your desired acceleration then compare to the torque the motor and gearing will provide and the belt will hold. Or just build it and test it. If in doubt just test it until you have a good gut feel for what will work and what needs calculating.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-01-14T02:11:50.015Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":381,"readers_count":380,"score":76.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":450055,"topic_slug":"180-1-max-planetary-60-1-belt-3-1","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/180-1-max-planetary-60-1-belt-3-1/450055/3","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3283844,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-14T02:16:49.121Z","cooked":"
Chadfrom7226:

You might run into belt issues with that much torque. Depends on the application, of course.

And the belt size. Wider belts can handle more torque, in general*. But for FRC packaging purposes, I’d be thinking chain–double chain if necessary.

*Can’t really talk from personal experience, but I’ve seen and worked with a few wide belts handling heavy loads.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-01-14T02:16:49.121Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":322,"readers_count":321,"score":64.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":450055,"topic_slug":"180-1-max-planetary-60-1-belt-3-1","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/180-1-max-planetary-60-1-belt-3-1/450055/4","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3283848,"name":"Max Morehead","username":"Max_Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-14T02:20:34.756Z","cooked":"

How wide is the belt and how big is the pulley?

Generally, it’s preferred to use chain on arms, especially ones that are going to support the weight of the robot, as in the Unqualified quokkas design. Last year we used #35 chain on 64T sprocket for our arm, but my understanding is you can get away with 25 or #25H (would recommend #35 though).

If you want to use belts, I would recommend looking at the load rating of your belt and calculating whether that’s less than the load of your arm, and like Patrick said, many people in FRC are just good at guessing.

Here are some resource on Arm design:

330 was a team that retired in 2019 but was one of the best teams in FRC, known for their single jointed arms: Guide to the classic 330 arm:

Arm Geometry Technical Discussion
Something something the Beach Bot Binder eventually? The “classic” 330 style arm, like all things in FRC, is a series of compromises between ease of manufacturing and programming, mechanical complexity, and ability to complete game challenges. [image] A single jointed arm is a massive lever- everything stems from this. The 8" diameter sprocket is bolted directly to the arm member as far from the axis of rotation as possible; using a hex shaft to transfer rotation at the requisite torque will …

How we will likely build our arm this year:

Aluminium tubing for frc arms Technical Discussion
Ok, sorry for the delay. So when designing our arm for 2023 we were very keen to learn the lessons from 2019 where our carriage arm died in just about every way imaginable (twisted hex shaft, shattered VersaPlanetaries, shattered 20DP gears). Your post is specifically about the axle so here’s some our design criteria specifically relating to the dead axle: Dead axle. This was # 1 on the list. Dead axls transferes the torque to the arm directly rather than indirectly through the shaft, it’s ju…

Another resource I saw last year:

A Guide to Designing Robust Robot Arms Technical
Google Doc with Edits for feedback and comments Intro Many teams are trying arms for this season, and it can sometimes get confusing with all the considerations and parts you need to make a well-designed arm. I’ve noticed some attempts at copying 7461’s arm, and there are some things I didn’t take note of that might be useful when designing your own. Hopefully, this guide isn’t too late in the season. Feel free to ask questions or message me if you need help. This guide might have some errors…

Rev dead axle example:

docs.revrobotics.com

Tubes / Bushings / Axles

ION BUILD SYSTEM","clicks":6},{"url":"/tag/25","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/arm-geometry/388784/5","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Arm Geometry","clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/aluminium-tubing-for-frc-arms/440625/20","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Aluminium tubing for frc arms","clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/a-guide-to-designing-robust-robot-arms/425684","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"A Guide to Designing Robust Robot Arms","clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/intake-in-n-out-systems-pneumatics-vs-motor/453436/9","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Intake In-n-Out systems, pneumatics vs motor","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53784,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/180-1-max-planetary-60-1-belt-3-1/450055/5","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3283862,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-14T02:36:28.696Z","cooked":"

Counterbalancing doesn’t solve every problem, but dang it does solve a lot of problems.

Gas springs are relatively cheap and pretty robust to Grand Canyon tolerance mismatch with the ball joints.

As far as chain and belts. You can use double sprockets to add strength, you can use belt tooth profiles that are aggressive to transfer more torque.

To decrease loads on the belt/chain go for as large of diameter as possible that results in the ratio you want, this promotes tooth engagement and you trade a higher belt surface speed for lower tension forces. The surface speed is a non issue in this application, so go big or go home. This makes the next point easier, as the angular error from a tiny amount of slop is less.

Things will generally need to be very tight to reduce backlash. These demands get less and the system should run smoother with less friction when you up pulley sizes. Instead of 20:60 go for 40:120 if it fits. Same reduction, less load on the chain or belt.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-01-14T02:43:53.528Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":184,"readers_count":183,"score":36.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":450055,"topic_slug":"180-1-max-planetary-60-1-belt-3-1","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/180-1-max-planetary-60-1-belt-3-1/450055/6","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3283937,"name":"Stewart Riley","username":"Strategic","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/strategic/{size}/10157_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-14T04:07:19.331Z","cooked":"

As has been noted, you might be able to get away with belts, but chain for this application is probably a better bet. If you look back at the Quakka’s arm, you’ll see that they’re using #35 chain.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-01-14T04:07:19.331Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":131,"readers_count":130,"score":36.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":450055,"topic_slug":"180-1-max-planetary-60-1-belt-3-1","display_username":"Stewart Riley","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32783,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"I plan, therefore I am"},"post_url":"/t/180-1-max-planetary-60-1-belt-3-1/450055/7","custom_user_title":"I plan, therefore I am","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3284100,"name":"Elliot S","username":"ElliotS","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elliots/{size}/177628_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-14T13:54:14.831Z","cooked":"

If you entire shooter is on the arm I would highly recommend using 35 chain instead of 25. It is heavier but it won’t break. I saw at least one team that would have their 25 chain regularly brake last season.

after discussing with the team about using chains instead of belts, we planned to buy this (i’m from brazil, so the site is in portuguese) kit of a 14T pinion an a 45T sprocket of a motorcycle. i think is robust enought for the aplication

Just be careful you aren’t kicking the can down the road to about weak point, sometimes they can appear in hard to see places.
